verses.text: Fragments of Clemens Alexandrinus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:2
verses.text: Translated by Rev.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:3
verses.text: William Wilson, M.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:5
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:6
verses.text: —From the Latin Translation of Cassiodorus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:7
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:8
verses.text: —Comments On the First Epistle of Peter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:9
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:10
verses.text: i "Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who by His great mercy hath regenerated us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:11
verses.text: For if God generated us of matter, He afterwards, by progress in life, regenerated us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:12
verses.text: "The Father of our Lord, by the resurrection of Jesus Christ:" who, according to your faith, rises again in us; as, on the other hand, He dies in us, through the operation of our unbelief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:13
verses.text: For He said again, that the soul never returns a second time to the body in this life; and that which has become angelic does not become unrighteous or evil, so as not to have the opportunity of again sinning by the assumption of flesh; but that in the resurrection the soul returns to the body, and both are joined to one another according to their peculiar nature, adapting themselves, through the composition of each, by a kind of congruity like a building of stones.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:14
verses.text: Besides, Peter says, "Ye also, as living stones, are built up a spiritual house;" meaning the place of the angelic abode, guarded in heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:15
verses.text: "For you," he says, "who are kept by the power of God, by faith and contemplation, to receive the end of your faith, the salvation of your souls".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:16
verses.text: Hence it appears that the soul is not naturally immortal; but is made immortal by the grace of God, through faith and righteousness, and by knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:17
verses.text: "Of which salvation," he says, "the prophets have inquired and searched diligently," and what follows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:18
verses.text: It is declared by this that the prophets spake with wisdom, and that the Spirit of Christ was in them, according to the possession of Christ, and in subjection to Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:19
verses.text: For God works through archangels and kindred angels, who are called spirits of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:20
verses.text: "Which are now," he says, "reported unto you by them that have preached the Gospel unto you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:21
verses.text: The old things which were done by the prophets and escape the observation of most, are now revealed to you by the evangelists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:22
verses.text: "For to you," he says, "they are manifested by the Holy Ghost, who was sent;" that is the Paraclete, of whom the Lord said, "If I go not away, He will not come".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:23
verses.text: "Unto whom," it is said, "the angels desire to look;" not the apostate angels, as most suspect, but, what is a divine truth, angels who desire to obtain the advantage of that perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:24
verses.text: "By precious blood," he says, "as of a lamb without blemish and without spot".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:25
verses.text: Here he touches on the ancient Levitical and sacerdotal celebrations; but means a soul pure through righteousness which is offered to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:26
verses.text: "Verily foreknown before the foundation of the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:27
verses.text: Inasmuch as He was foreknown before every creature, because He was Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:28
verses.text: "But manifested in the last times" by the generation of a body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:29
verses.text: "Being born again, not of corruptible seed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:30
verses.text: The soul, then, which is produced along with the body is corruptible, as some think.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:31
verses.text: "But the word of the Lord," he says, "endureth for ever:" as well prophecy as divine doctrine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:32
verses.text: "But ye are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:33
verses.text: That we are a chosen race by the election of God is abundantly clear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:34
verses.text: He says royal, because we are called to sovereignty and belong to Christ; and priesthood on account of the oblation which is made by prayers and instructions, by which are gained the souls which are offered to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:35
verses.text: "Who, when He was reviled," he says, "reviled not; when He suffered, threatened not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:36
verses.text: The Lord acted so in His goodness and patience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:37
verses.text: "But committed Himself to him that judged Him unrighteously:" whether Himself, so that, regarding Himself in this way, there is a transposition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:38
verses.text: He indeed gave Himself up to those who judged according to an unjust law; because He was unserviceable to them, inasmuch as He was righteous: or, He committed to God those who judged unrighteously, and without cause insisted on His death, so that they might be instructed by suffering punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:39
verses.text: "For he that will love life, and see good days;" that is, who wishes to become eternal and immortal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:40
verses.text: And He calls the Lord life, and the days good, that is holy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:41
verses.text: "For the eyes of the Lord," he says, "are upon the righteous, and His ears on their prayers:" he means the manifold inspection of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:42
verses.text: "The face of the Lord is on them that do evil;" that is, whether judgment, or vengeance, or manifestation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:43
verses.text: "But sanctify the Lord Christ," he says, "in your hearts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:44
verses.text: For so you have in the Lord's prayer, "Hallowed be Thy name".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:45
verses.text: "For Christ," he says, "hath once suffered for our sins, the just for the unjust, that he might present us to God; being put to death in the flesh, but quickened in the spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:46
verses.text: He says these things, reducing them to their faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:47
verses.text: That is, He became alive in our spirits.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:48
verses.text: "Coming," he says, "He preached to those who were once unbelieving".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:49
verses.text: They saw not His form, but they heard His voice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:50
verses.text: "When the long-suffering of God" holds out.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:51
verses.text: God is so good, as to work the result by the teaching of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:52
verses.text: "By the resurrection," it is said, "of Jesus Christ:" that, namely, which is effected in us by faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:53
verses.text: "Angels being subjected to Him," which are the first order; and "principalities" being subject, who are of the second order; and "powers" being also subject, which are said to belong to the third order.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:54
verses.text: "Who shall give account," he says, "to Him who is ready to judge the quick and the dead".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:55
verses.text: These are trained through previous judgments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:56
verses.text: Therefore he adds, "For this cause was the Gospel preached also to the dead"—to us, namely, who were at one time unbelievers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:57
verses.text: "That they might be judged according to men," he says, "in the flesh, but live according to God in the spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:58
verses.text: Because, that is, they have fallen away from faith; whilst they are still in the flesh they are judged according to preceding judgments, that they might repent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:59
verses.text: Accordingly, he also adds, saying, "That they might live according to God in the spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:60
verses.text: So Paul also; for he, too, states something of this nature when he says, "Whom I have delivered to Satan, that he might live in the spirit;" that is, "as good stewards of the manifold grace of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:61
verses.text: Similarly also Paul says, "Variously, and in many ways, God of old spake to our fathers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:62
verses.text: "Rejoice," it is said, "that ye are partakers in the sufferings of Christ:" that is, if ye are righteous, ye suffer for righteousness' sake, as Christ suffered for righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:63
verses.text: "Happy are ye, for the Spirit of God, who is the Spirit of His glory and virtue, resteth on you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:64
verses.text: This possessive "His" signifies also an an angelic spirit: inasmuch as the glory of God those are, through whom, according to faith and righteousness, He is glorified, to honourable glory, according to the advancement of the saints who are brought in.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:65
verses.text: "The Spirit of God on us," may be thus understood; that is, who through faith comes on the soul, like a gracefulness of mind and beauty of soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:66
verses.text: "Since," it is said, "it is time for judgment beginning at the house of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:67
verses.text: For judgment will overtake these in the appointed persecutions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:68
verses.text: "But the God of all grace," he says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:69
verses.text: "Of all grace," he says, because He is good, and the giver of all good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:70
verses.text: "Marcus, my son, saluteth you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:71
verses.text: Mark, the follower of Peter, while Peter publicly preached the Gospel at Rome before some of Caesar's equites, and adduced many testimonies to Christ, in order that thereby they might be able to commit to memory what was spoken, of what was spoken by Peter, wrote entirely what is called the Gospel according to Mark.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 1:72
verses.text: As Luke also may be recognised by the style, both to have composed the Acts of the Apostles, and to have translated Paul's Epistle to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:1
verses.text: 2—Comments on the Epistle of Jude.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:2
verses.text: Jude, who wrote the Catholic Epistle, the brother of the sons of Joseph, and very religious, whilst knowing the near relationship of the Lord, yet did not say that he himself was His brother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:3
verses.text: But what said he? "Jude, a servant of Jesus Christ,"—of Him as Lord; but "the brother of James".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:4
verses.text: For this is true; he was His brother, (the son) of Joseph.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:5
verses.text: "For certain men have entered unawares, ungodly men, who had been of old ordained and predestined to the judgment of our God;" not that they might become impious, but that, being now impious, they were ordained to judgment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:6
verses.text: "For the Lord God," he says, "who once delivered a people out of Egypt, afterward destroyed them that believed not;" that is, that He might train them through punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:7
verses.text: For they were indeed punished, and they perished on account of those that are saved, until they turn to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:8
verses.text: "But the angels," he says, "that kept not their own pre-eminence," that, namely, which they received through advancement, "but left their own habitation," meaning, that is, the heaven and the stars, became, and are called apostates.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:9
verses.text: "He hath reserved these to the judgment of the great day, in chains, under darkness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:10
verses.text: He means the place near the earth, that is, the dark air.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:11
verses.text: Now he called "chains" the loss of the honour in which they had stood, and the lust of feeble things; since, bound by their own lust, they cannot be converted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:12
verses.text: "As Sodom and Gomorrha," he says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:13
verses.text: … By which the Lord signifies that pardon had been granted; and that on being disciplined they had repented.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:14
verses.text: "Similarly to the same," he says, "also those dreamers,"—that is, who dream in their imagination lusts and wicked desires, regarding as good not that which is truly good, and superior to all good,—"defile the flesh, despise dominion, and speak evil of majesty," that is, the only Lord, who is truly our Lord, Jesus Christ, and alone worthy of praise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:15
verses.text: They "speak evil of majesty," that is, of the angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:16
verses.text: "When Michael, the archangel, disputing with the devil, debated about the body of Moses".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:17
verses.text: Here he confirms the assumption of Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:18
verses.text: He is here called Michael, who through an angel near to us debated with the devil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:19
verses.text: "But these," he says, "speak evil of those things which they know not; but what they know naturally, as brute beasts, in these things they corrupt themselves".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:20
verses.text: He means that they eat, and drink, and indulge in uncleanness, and says that they do other things that are common to them with animals, devoid of reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:21
verses.text: "Woe unto them!" he says, "for they have gone in the way of Cain".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:22
verses.text: For so also we lie under Adam's sin through similarity of sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:23
verses.text: "Clouds," he says, "without water; who do not possess in themselves the divine and fruitful word".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:24
verses.text: Wherefore, he says, "men of this kind are carried about both by winds and violent blasts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:25
verses.text: "Trees," he says, "of autumn, without fruit,"—unbelievers, that is, who bear no fruit of fidelity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:26
verses.text: "Twice dead," he says: once, namely, when they sinned by transgressing, and a second time when delivered up to punishment, according to the predestined judgments of God; inasmuch as it is to be reckoned death, even when each one does not forthwith deserve the inheritance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:27
verses.text: "Waves," he says, "of a raging sea".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:28
verses.text: By these words he signifies the life of the Gentiles, whose end is abominable ambition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:29
verses.text: "Wandering stars,"—that is, he means those who err and are apostates are of that kind of stars which fell from the seats of the angels—"to whom," for their apostasy, "the blackness of darkness is reserved for ever.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:30
verses.text: Enoch also, the seventh from Adam," he says, "prophesied of these".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:31
verses.text: In these words he verities the prophecy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:32
verses.text: "Those," he says, "separating" the faithful from the unfaithful, be convicted according to their own unbelief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:33
verses.text: And again those separating from the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:34
verses.text: He says, "Animal not having  the spirit;" that is, the spirit which is by faith, which supervenes through the practice of righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:35
verses.text: "But ye, beloved," he says, "building up yourselves on your most holy faith, in the Holy Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:36
verses.text: "But some," he says, "save, plucking them from the fire;" "but of some have compassion in fear," that is, teach those who fall into the fire to free themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:37
verses.text: "Hating," he says, "that spotted garment, which is carnal:" that of the soul, namely; the spotted garment is a spirit polluternal lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:38
verses.text: "Now to Him," he says, "who is able to keep you without stumbling, and present you faultless before the presence of His glory in joy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:39
verses.text: In the presence of His glory: he means in the presence of the angels, to be presented faultless, having become angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:40
verses.text: When Daniel speaks of the people and comes into the presence of the Lord, he does not say this, because he saw God: for it is impossible that any one whose heart is not pure should see God; but he says this, that everything that the people did was in the sight of God, and was manifest to Him; that is, that nothing is hid from the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:41
verses.text: Now, in the Gospel according to Mark, the Lord being interrogated by the chief of the priests if He was the Christ, the Son of the blessed God, answering, said, "I am; and ye shall see the Son of man sitting at the right hand of power".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:42
verses.text: But powers mean the holy angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:43
verses.text: Further, when He says "at the right hand of God," He means the self-same beings, by reason of the equality and likeness of the angelic and holy powers, which are called by the name of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:44
verses.text: He says, therefore, that He sits at the right hand; that is, that He rests in pre-eminent honour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:45
verses.text: In the other Gospels, however, He is said not to have replied to the high priest, on his asking if He was the Son of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:46
verses.text: But what said He? "You say".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:47
verses.text: Answering sufficiently well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:48
verses.text: For had He said, It is as you understand, he would have said what was not true, not confessing Himself to be the Son of God; for they did not entertain this opinion of Him; but by saying "You say," He spake truly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 2:49
verses.text: For what they had no knowledge of, but expressed in words, that he confessed to be true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:1
verses.text: 3—Comments on the First Epistle of John.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:2
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:3
verses.text: i "That which was from the beginning; which we have seen with our eyes; which we have heard".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:4
verses.text: Following the Gospel according to John, and in accordance with it, this Epistle also contains the spiritual principle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:5
verses.text: What therefore he says, "from the beginning," the Presbyter explained to this effect, that the beginning of generation is not separated from the beginning of the Creator.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:6
verses.text: For when he says, "That which was from the beginning," he touches upon the generation without beginning of the Son, who is co-existent with the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:7
verses.text: There was; then, a Word importing an unbeginning eternity; as also the Word itself, that is, the Son of God, who being, by equality of substance, one with the Father, is eternal and uncreate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:8
verses.text: That He was always the Word, is signified by saying, "In the beginning was the Word".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:9
verses.text: But by the expression, "we have seen with our eyes," he signifies the Lord's presence in the flesh, "and our hands have handled," he says, "of the Word of life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:10
verses.text: He means not only His flesh, but the virtues of the Son, like the sunbeam which penetrates to the lowest places,—this sunbeam coming in the flesh became palpable to the disciples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:11
verses.text: It is accordingly related in traditions, that John, touching the outward body itself, sent his hand deep down into it, and that the solidity of the flesh offered no obstacle, but gave way to the hand of the disciple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:12
verses.text: "And our hands have handled of the Word of life;" that is, He who came in the flesh became capable of being touched.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:13
verses.text: As also,  Ver "The life was manifested".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:14
verses.text: For in the Gospel he thus speaks: "And what was made, in Him was life, and the life was the light of men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:15
verses.text: "And we show unto you that eternal life, which was with the Father, and was manifested unto you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:16
verses.text: He signifies by the appellation of Father, that the Son also existed always, without beginning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:17
verses.text: Ver "For God," he says, "is light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:18
verses.text: He does not express the divine essence, but wishing to declare the majesty of God, he has applied to the Divinity what is best and most excellent in the view of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:19
verses.text: Thus also Paul, when he speaks of "light inaccessible".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:20
verses.text: But John himself also in this same Epistle says, "God is love:" pointing out the excellences of God, that He is kind and merciful; and because He is light, makes men righteous, according to the advancement of the soul,  through charity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:21
verses.text: God, then, who is ineffable in respect of His substance, is light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:22
verses.text: "And in Him is no darkness at all,"—that is, no passion, no keeping up of evil respecting any one, He destroys no one, but gives salvation to all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:23
verses.text: Light moreover signifies, either the precepts of the Law, or faith, or doctrine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:24
verses.text: Darkness is the opposite of these things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:25
verses.text: Not as if there were another way; since there is only one way according to the divine precepts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:26
verses.text: For the work of God is unity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:27
verses.text: Duality and all else that exists, except unity, arises from perversity of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:28
verses.text: Ver "And the blood of Jesus Christ His Son," he says, "cleanses us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:29
verses.text: For the doctrine of the Lord, which is very powerful, is called His blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:30
verses.text: Ver "If we say that we have not sinned, we make Him a liar, and His word is not in us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:31
verses.text: His doctrine, that is, or word is truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:32
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:33
verses.text: ii "And if any man sin," he says, "we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:34
verses.text: For so the Lord is an advocate with the Father for us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:35
verses.text: So also is there, an advocate, whom, after His assumption, He vouchsafed to send.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:36
verses.text: For these primitive and first-created virtues are unchangeable as to substance, and along with subordinate angels and archangels, whose names they share, effect divine operations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:37
verses.text: Thus also Moses names the virtue of the angel Michael, by an angel near to himself and of lowest grade.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:38
verses.text: The like also we find in the holy prophets; but to Moses an angel appeared near and at hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:39
verses.text: Moses heard him and spoke to him manifestly, face to face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:40
verses.text: On the other prophets, through the agency of angels, an impression was made, as of beings hearing and seeing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:41
verses.text: On this account also, they alone heard, and they alone saw; as also is seen in the case of Samuel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:42
verses.text: Elisaeus also alone heard the voice by which he was called.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:43
verses.text: If the voice had been open and common, it would have been heard by all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:44
verses.text: In this instance it was heard by him alone in whom the impression made by the angel worked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:45
verses.text: Ver "And not only for our sins,"—that is for those of the faithful,—is the Lord the propitiator, does he say, "but also for the whole world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:46
verses.text: He, indeed, saves all; but some He saves, converting them by punishments; others, however, who follow voluntarily He saves with dignity of honour; so "that every knee should bow to Him, of things in heaven, and things on earth, and things under the earth;" that is, angels, men, and souls that before His advent have departed from this temporal life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:47
verses.text: Ver "And by this we know that we know Him, if we keep His commandments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:48
verses.text: For the Gnostic he who knows also does the Works which pertain to the province of virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:49
verses.text: But he who performs the works is not necessarily also a Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:50
verses.text: For a man may be a doer of right works, and yet not a knower of the mysteries of science.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:51
verses.text: Finally, knowing that some works are performed from fear of punishment, and some on account of the promise of reward, he shows the perfection of the man gifted with knowledge, who fulfils his works by love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:52
verses.text: Further, he adds, and says:—  Ver "But whoso keepeth His word, in him verily is the love of God perfected: hereby know we that we are in Him,"—by faith and love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:53
verses.text: Ver "I write no new commandment unto you, but an old commandment, which ye had from the beginning,"—through the Law, that is, and the prophets; where it is said, God is one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:54
verses.text: Accordingly, also, he infers, "For the old commandment is the word which ye have heard".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:55
verses.text: Again, however, he says:—  Ver "This is the commandment; for the darkness" of perversion, that is, "has passed away, and, lo, the true light hath already shone,"—that is, through faith, through knowledge, through the Covenant working in men, through prepared judgments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:56
verses.text: Ver "He that saith he is in the light,"—in the light, he means in the truth,—"and hateth," he says, "his brother".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:57
verses.text: By his brother, he means not only his neighbour, but also the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:58
verses.text: For unbelievers hate Him and do not keep His commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:59
verses.text: Therefore also he infers:—  Ver "He that loveth his brother abideth in the light; and there is none occasion of stumbling in him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:60
verses.text: Vers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:62
verses.text: He then indicates the stages of advancement and progress of souls that are still located in the flesh; and calls those whose sins have been forgiven, for the Lord's name's sake, "little children," for many believe on account of the name only.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:63
verses.text: He styles "fathers" the perfect, "who have known what was from the beginning," and received with understanding,—the Son, that is, of whom he said above, "that which was from the beginning".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:64
verses.text: "I write," says he, "to you, young men, because ye have overcome the wicked one".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:65
verses.text: Young man strong in despising pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:66
verses.text: "The wicked one" points out the eminence of the devil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:67
verses.text: "The children," moreover, know the Father; having fled from idols and gathered together to the one God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:68
verses.text: Ver "For the world," he says, "is in the  wicked one".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:69
verses.text: Is not the world, and all that is in the world, called God's creation and very good? Yes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:70
verses.text: But,  Ver "The lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes, and the ambition of the world," which arise from the perversion of life, "are not of the Father, but of the world," and of you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:71
verses.text: Ver "Therefore also the world shall pass away, and the lust thereof; but he that doeth the will of God" and His commandments "abideth for ever".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:72
verses.text: Ver "They went out from us; but they were not of us"—neither the apostate angels, nor men falling away;—"but that they may be manifested that they are not of us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:73
verses.text: With sufficient clearness he distinguishes the class of the elect and that of the lost, and that which remaining in faith "has an unction from the Holy One," which comes through faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:74
verses.text: He that abideth not in faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:75
verses.text: Ver "A liar" and "an antichrist, who denieth that Jesus is the Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:76
verses.text: For Jesus, Saviour and Redeemer, is also Christ the King.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:77
verses.text: Ver "He who denies the Son," by ignoring Him, "has not the Father, nor does he know Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:78
verses.text: But he who knoweth the Son and the Father, knows according to knowledge, and when the Lord shall be manifested at His second advent, shall have confidence and not be confounded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:79
verses.text: Which confusion is heavy punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:80
verses.text: Ver "Every one," he says, "who doeth righteousness is born of God;" being regenerated, that is, according to faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:81
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:82
verses.text: iii "For the world knoweth us not, as it knew Him not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:83
verses.text: He means by the world those who live a worldly life in pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:84
verses.text: Ver "Beloved," says he, "now are we the sons of God," not by natural affection, but because we have God as our Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:85
verses.text: For it is the greater love that, seeing we have no relationship to God, He nevertheless loves us and calls us His sons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:86
verses.text: "And it hath not yet appeared what we shall be;" that is, to what kind of glory we shall attain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:87
verses.text: "For if He shall be manifested,"—that is, if we are made perfect,—"we shall be like Him," as reposing and justified, pure in virtue, "so that we may see Him" (His countenance) "as He is," by comprehension.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:88
verses.text: Ver "He that doeth unrighteousness is of the devil," that is, of the devil as his father, following and choosing the same things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:89
verses.text: "The devil sinneth from the beginning," he says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:90
verses.text: From the beginning from which he began to sin, incorrigibly persevering in sinning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:91
verses.text: Ver He says, "Whosoever is born of God does not commit sin, for His seed remaineth in him;" that is, His word in him who is born again through faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:92
verses.text: Ver "Thus we know the children of God, as likewise the children of the devil," who choose things like the devil; for so also they are said to be of the wicked one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:93
verses.text: Ver "Every one who hateth his brother is a murderer".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:94
verses.text: For in him through unbelief Christ dies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:95
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, he continues, "And ye know that no murderer and unbeliever hath eternal life abiding in him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:96
verses.text: For the living Christ abides in the believing soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:97
verses.text: Ver "For He Himself laid down His life for us;" that is, for those who believe; that is, for the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:98
verses.text: If then He laid down His life for the apostles, he means His apostles themselves: us if he said, We, I say, the apostles, for whom He laid down His life, "ought to lay down our lives for the brethren;" for the salvation of their neighbours was the glory of the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:99
verses.text: Ver He says, "For God is greater than our heart;" that is, the virtue of God is greater than conscience, which will follow the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:100
verses.text: Wherefore he continues, and says, "and knoweth all things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:101
verses.text: Ver "Beloved, if our heart condemn us not, it will have confidence before God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:102
verses.text: Ver "And hereby we know that He dwelleth in us by His Spirit, which He hath given us;" that is, by superintendence and foresight of future events.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:103
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:104
verses.text: iv He says, "Perfect love casteth out fear".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:105
verses.text: For the perfection of a believing man is love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:106
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:107
verses.text: v He says, "This is He who came by water and blood;" and again,—  Ver "For there are three that bear witness, the spirit," which is life, "and the water," which is regeneration and faith, "and the blood," which is knowledge; "and these three are one".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:108
verses.text: For in the Saviour are those saving virtues, and life itself exists in His own Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:109
verses.text: Ver "And this is the confidence which we have towards Him, that if we ask anything according to His will, He will hear us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:110
verses.text: He does not say absolutely what we shall ask, but what we ought to ask.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:111
verses.text: Ver "And the whole word lieth in the wicked one;" not the creation, but worldly men, and those who live according to their lusts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 3:112
verses.text: Ver "And the Son of God hath come and given us understanding," which comes to us, that is, by faith, and is also called the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:1
verses.text: 4—Comments on the Second Epistle of John.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:2
verses.text: The second Epistle of John, which is written to Virgins, is very simple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:3
verses.text: It was written to a Babylonian lady, by name Electa, and indicates  the election of the holy Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:4
verses.text: He establishes in this Epistle that the following out of the faith is not without charity, and so that no one divide Jesus Christ; but only to believe that Jesus Christ has come in the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:5
verses.text: For he who has the Son by apprehension in his intellect knows also the Father, and grasps with his mind intelligibly the greatness of His power working without beginning of time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:6
verses.text: Ver He says, "If any come unto you and bring not this doctrine, receive him not into your house, neither bid him God speed; for he that biddeth him God speed is partaker of his evil deeds".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:7
verses.text: He forbids us to salute such, and to receive them to our hospitality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:8
verses.text: For this is not harsh in the case of a man of this sort.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:9
verses.text: But he admonishes them neither to confer nor dispute with such as are not able to handle divine things with intelligence, lest through them they be seduced from the doctrine of truth, influenced by plausible reasons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:10
verses.text: Now, I think that we are not even to pray with such, because in the prayer which is made at home, after rising from prayer, the salutation of joy is also the token of peace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:11
verses.text: 2—Nicetas Bishop of Heraclea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:12
verses.text: From His Catena.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:13
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:14
verses.text: —Job i  But Job's words may be more elegantly understood of evil and sin thus: "Naked" was formed from the earth at the beginning, as if from a "mother's womb: naked to the earth shall I also depart;" naked, not of possessions, for that were a trivial and common thing, but of evil and sin, and of the unsightly shape which follows those who have led bad lives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:15
verses.text: Obviously, all of us human beings are born naked, and again are buried naked, swathed only in grave-clothes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:16
verses.text: For God hath provided for us another life, and made the present life the way for the course which leads to it; appointing the supplies derived from what we possess merely as provisions for the way; and on our quitting this way, the wealth, consisting of the things which we possessed, journeys no farther with us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:17
verses.text: For not a single thing that we possess is properly our own: of one possession alone, that is godliness, are we properly owners.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:18
verses.text: Of this, death, when it overtakes us, will not rob us; but from all else it will eject us, though against our will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:19
verses.text: For it is for the support of life that we all have received what we possess; and after enjoying merely the use of it, each one departs, obtaining from life a brief remembrance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:20
verses.text: For this is the end of all prosperity; this is the conclusion of the good things of this life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:21
verses.text: Well, then, does the infant, on opening its eyes, after issuing from the womb, immediately begin with crying, not with laughter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:22
verses.text: For it weeps, as if bewailing life, at whose hands from the outset it tastes of deadly gifts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:23
verses.text: For immediately on being born its hands and feet are swaddled; and swathed in bonds it takes the breast.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:24
verses.text: O introduction to life, precursor of death! The child has but just entered on life, and straightway there is put upon it the raiment of the dead: for nature reminds those that are born of their end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:25
verses.text: Wherefore also the child, on being born, wails, as if crying plaintively to its mother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:26
verses.text: Why, O mother, didst thou bring me forth to this life, in which prolongation of life is progress to death? Why hast thou brought me into this troubled world, in which, on being born, swaddling bands are my first experience? Why hast thou delivered me to such a life as this, in which both a pitiable youth wastes away before old age, and old age is shunned as under the doom of death? Dreadful, O mother, is the course of life, which has death as the goal of the runner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:27
verses.text: Bitter is the road of life we travel, with the grave as the wayfarer's inn.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:28
verses.text: Perilous the sea of life we sail; for it has Hades as a pirate to attack us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:29
verses.text: Man alone is born in all respects naked, without a weapon or clothing born with him; not as being inferior to the other animals, but that nakedness and your bringing nothing with you may produce thought; and that thought may bring out dexterity, expel sloth, introduce the arts for the supply of our needs, and beget variety of contrivances.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:30
verses.text: For, naked, man is full of contrivances, being pricked on by his necessity, as by a goad, how to escape rains, how to elude cold, how to fence off blows, how to till the earth, how to terrify wild beasts, how to subdue the more powerful of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:31
verses.text: Wetted with rain, he contrived a roof; having suffered from cold, he invented clothing; being struck, he constructed a breastplate; bleeding his hands with the thorns in tilling the ground, he availed himself of the help of tools; in his naked state liable to become a prey to wild beasts, he discovered from his fear an art which frightened what frightened him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:32
verses.text: Nakedness begat one accomplishment after another; so that even his nakedness was a gift and a master-favour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:33
verses.text: Accordingly, Job also being made naked of wealth, possessions, of the blessing of children, of a numerous offspring, and having lost everything in a short time, uttered this grateful exclamation: "Naked came I out of the womb, naked also shall I depart thither;"—to God, that is, and to that blessed lot and rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:34
verses.text: 2—From the Same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:35
verses.text: Job v Calmness is a thing which, of all other things, is most to be prized.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:36
verses.text: As an example  of this, the word proposes to us the blessed Job.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:37
verses.text: For it is said of him, "What man is like Job, who drinketh up scorning like water?" For truly enviable, and, in my judgment, worthy of all admiration, a man is, if he has attained to such a degree of long-suffering as to be able with ease to grapple with the pain, truly keen, and not easily conquered by everybody, which arises from being wronged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:38
verses.text: 3—From Nicetas' Catena on Matthew.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:39
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:40
verses.text: v Alms are to be given, but with judgment, and to the deserving, that we may obtain a recompense from the Most High.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:41
verses.text: But woe to those who have and who take under false pretences, or who are able to help themselves and want to take from others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:42
verses.text: For he who has, and, to carry out false pretences or out of laziness, takes, shall be condemned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:43
verses.text: 4—From the Same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:44
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:45
verses.text: xiii The word which proclaims the kingdom of heaven is sharp and pungent as mustard, and represses bile, that is, anger, and checks inflammation, that is, pride; and from this word the soul's true health and eternal soundness flow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:46
verses.text: To such increased size did the growth of the word come, that the tree which sprang from it (that is the Church of Christ established over the whole earth) filled the world, so that the fowls of the air—that is, divine angels and lofty souls—dwelt in its branches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:47
verses.text: 5—From the Same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:48
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:49
verses.text: xiii A pearl, and that pellucid and of purest ray, is Jesus, whom of the lightning flash of Divinity the Virgin bore.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:50
verses.text: For as the pearl, produced in flesh and the oyster-shell and moisture, appears to be a body moist and transparent, full of light and spirit; so also God the Word, incarnate, is intellectual light, sending His rays, through a body luminous and moist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:51
verses.text: 3—From the Catena on Luke, Edited by Corderius.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:52
verses.text: Luke iii God here assumed the "likeness" not of a man, but "of a dove," because He wished, by a new apparition of the Spirit in the likeness of a dove, to declare His simplicity and majesty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:53
verses.text: Luke xvi Perhaps by the iota and tittle His righteousness cries, "If ye come right unto Me, I will also come right to you; but if crooked, I also will come crooked, saith the Lord of hosts;" intimating that the ways of sinners are intricate and crooked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:54
verses.text: For the way right and agreeable to nature which is intimated by the iota of Jesus, is His goodness, which constantly directs those who believe from hearing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:55
verses.text: "There shall not, therefore, pass from the law one iota or one tittle," neither from the right and good the mutual promises, nor from the crooked and unjust the punishment assigned to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:56
verses.text: "For the Lord doeth good to the good, but those who turn aside into crooked ways God will lead with the workers of iniquity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:57
verses.text: 4—From the Books of the Hypotyposes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:58
verses.text: oecumenius from Book 3 On  Cor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:59
verses.text: xi  "Because of the angels".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:60
verses.text: By the angels he means righteous and virtuous men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:61
verses.text: Let her be veiled then, that she may not lead them to stumble into fornication.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:62
verses.text: For the real angels in heaven see her though veiled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:63
verses.text: The Same, Book 4 On  Cor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:64
verses.text: v  "And if we have known Christ after the flesh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:65
verses.text: As "after the flesh" in our case is being in the midst of sins, and being out of them is "not after the flesh;" so also "after the flesh" in the case of Christ was His subjection to natural affections, and His not being subject to them is to be "not after the flesh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:66
verses.text: But, he says, as He was released, so also are we.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:67
verses.text: The Same, Book 4 On  Cor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:68
verses.text: vi  "Our heart is enlarged," to teach you all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:69
verses.text: But ye are straitened in your own bowels, that is, in love to God, in which ye ought to love me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:70
verses.text: The Same, Book 5 On Gal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:71
verses.text: v  "And they that are Christ's have crucified the flesh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:72
verses.text: And why mention one aspect of virtue after another? For there are some who have crucified themselves as far as the passions are concerned, and the passions as far as respects themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:73
verses.text: According to this interpretation the "and" is not superfluous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:74
verses.text: "And they that are Christ's"—that is, striving after Him—"have crucified their own flesh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:75
verses.text: Moschus: Spiritual Meadow, Book 5 Chap  Yes, truly, the apostles were baptised, as Clement the Stromatist relates in the fifth book of the Hypotyposes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:76
verses.text: For, in explaining the apostolic statement, "I thank God that I baptised none of you," he says, Christ is said to have baptised Peter alone, and Peter Andrew, and Andrew John, and they James and the rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:77
verses.text: Eusebius: Ecclesiastical History, Book 6 2  Now Clement, writing in the sixth book of the Hypotyposes, makes this statement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:78
verses.text: For he says that Peter and James and John, after the Saviour's ascension, though pre-eminently honoured by the Lord, did not contend for glory, but made James the Just, bishop of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:79
verses.text: Eusebius: Ecclesiastical History, II  So, then, through the visit of the divine word to them, the power of Simon was extinguished, and immediately was destroyed along with the man himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:80
verses.text: And such a ray of godliness shone forth on the minds of Peter's hearers, that they were not satisfied with the once hearing or with the unwritten teaching of the divine proclamation, but with all manner of entreaties importuned Mark, to whom the Gospel is ascribed, he being the companion of Peter, that he would leave in writing a record of the teaching which had been delivered to them verbally; and did not let the man alone till they prevailed upon him; and so to them we owe the Scripture called the "Gospel by Mark".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:81
verses.text: On learning what had been done, through the revelation of the Spirit, it is said that the apostle was delighted with the enthusiasm of the men, and sanctioned the composition for reading in the Churches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:82
verses.text: Clemens gives the narrative in the sixth book of the Hypotyposes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:83
verses.text: Eusebius: Ibid.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:84
verses.text: Then, also, as the divine Scripture says, Herod, on the execution of James, seeing that what was done pleased the Jews, laid hands also on Peter; and having put him in chains, would have presently put him to death, had not an angel in a divine vision appeared to him by night, and wondrously releasing him from his bonds, sent him away to the ministry of preaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:85
verses.text: Eusebius: Ecclesiastical History, VI  And in the Hypotyposes, in a word, he has made abbreviated narratives of the whole testamentary Scripture; and has not passed over the disputed books,—I mean Jude and the rest of the Catholic Epistles and Barnabas, and what is called the Revelation of Peter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 4:86
verses.text: And he says that the Epistle to the Hebrews is Paul's, and was written to the Hebrews in the Hebrew language; but that Luke, having carefully translated it, gave it to the Greeks, and hence the same colouring in the expression is discoverable in this Epistle and the Acts; and that the name "Paul an Apostle" was very properly not prefixed, for, he says, that writing to the Hebrews, who were prejudiced against him and suspected, he with great wisdom did not repel them in the beginning by putting down his name.

verses.text: He provides for his own and those of his own house, who not only provides for his relatives, but also for himself, by extirpating the passions.

verses.text: Tim.

verses.text: For these the apostle made witnesses of his own preaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:20
verses.text: Eusebius: Ecclesiastical History, Book 7 II  To James the Just, and John and Peter, the Lord after His resurrection imparted knowledge (τὴν γνῶσιν.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:21
verses.text: ) These imparted it to the rest of the apostles, and the rest of the apostles to the Seventy, of whom Barnabas was one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:22
verses.text: Eusebius: the Same, II  And of this James, Clement also relates an anecdote worthy of remembrance in the seventh book of the Hypotyposes, from a tradition of his predecessors.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:23
verses.text: He says that the man who brought him to trial, on seeing him bear his testimony, was moved, and confessed that he was a Christian himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:24
verses.text: Accordingly, he says, they were both led away together, and on the way the other asked James to forgive him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:25
verses.text: And he, considering a little, said, "Peace be to thee" and kissed him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:26
verses.text: And so both were beheaded together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:27
verses.text: Eusebius: the Same, VI  And now, as the blessed Presbyter used to say, since the Lord, as the Apostle of the Almighty, was sent to the Hebrews, Paul, as having been sent to the Gentiles, did not subscribe himself apostle of the Hebrews, out of modesty and reverence for the Lord, and because, being the herald and apostle of the Gentiles, his writing to the Hebrews was something over and above his assigned function.

verses.text: Eusebius: the Same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:29
verses.text: Again, in the same books Clement has set down a tradition which he had received from the elders before him, in regard to the order of the Gospels, to the following effect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:30
verses.text: He says that the Gospels containing the genealogies were written first, and that the Gospel according to Mark was composed in the following circumstances:—  Peter having preached the word publicly at Rome, and by the Spirit proclaimed the Gospel, those who were present, who were numerous, entreated Mark, inasmuch as he had attended him from an early period, and remembered what had been said, to write down what had been spoken.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:31
verses.text: On his composing the Gospel, he handed it to those who had made the request to him; which coming to Peter's knowledge, he neither hindered nor encouraged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:32
verses.text: But John, the last of all, seeing that what was corporeal was set forth in the Gospels, on the entreaty of his intimate friends, and inspired by the Spirit, composed a spiritual Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:36
verses.text: II  Being is in God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:37
verses.text: God is divine being, eternal and without beginning, incorporeal and illimitable, and the cause of what exists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:38
verses.text: Being is that which wholly subsists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:39
verses.text: Nature is the truth of things, or the inner reality of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:40
verses.text: According to others, it is the production of what has come to existence; and according to others, again, it is the providence of God, causing the being, and the manner of being, in the things which are produced.

verses.text: S.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:42
verses.text: Maximus: in the Same, p  Willing is a natural power, which desires what is in accordance with nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:43
verses.text: Willing is a natural appetency, corresponding with the nature of the rational creature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:44
verses.text: Willing is a natural spontaneous movement of the self-determining mind, or the mind voluntarily moved about anything.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:45
verses.text: Spontaneity is the mind moved naturally, or an intellectual self-determining movement of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:46
verses.text: 6—From the Book on the Soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:47
verses.text: Maximus and Antonius Melissa.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:48
verses.text: Souls that breathe free of all things, possess life, and though separated from the body, and found possessed of a longing for it, are borne immortal to the bosom of God: as in the winter season the vapours of the earth attracted by the sun's rays rise to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:49
verses.text: The Barocc.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:50
verses.text: ms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:51
verses.text: All souls are immortal, even those of the wicked, for whom it were better that they were not deathless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:52
verses.text: For, punished with the endless vengeance of quenchless fire, and not dying, it is impossible for them to have a period put to their misery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:53
verses.text: 7—Fragment from the Book on Slander.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:54

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:55
verses.text: Never be afraid of the slanderer who addresses you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:56
verses.text: But rather say, Stop, brother; I daily commit more grievous errors, and how can I judge him? For you will gain two things, healing with one plaster both yourself and your neighbour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:57
verses.text: He shows what is really evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:58
verses.text: Whence, by these arguments, God has contrived to make each one's disposition manifest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:66
verses.text: Repentance then becomes capable of wiping out every sin, when on the occurrence of the soul's fault it admits no delay, and does not let the impulse pass on to a long space of time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:67
verses.text: For it is in this way that evil will be unable to leave a trace in us, being plucked away at the moment of its assault like a newly planted plant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:68
verses.text: As the creatures called crabs are easy to catch, from their going sometimes forward and sometimes backward; so also the soul, which at one time is laughing, at another weeping, and at another giving way to luxury, can do no good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:69
verses.text: He who is sometimes grieving, and is sometimes enjoying himself and laughing, is like a man pelting the dog of voluptuousness with bread, who chases it in appearance, but in fact invites it to remain near him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:70
verses.text: Book 1 Sermon , on Praise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:71
verses.text: Some flatterers were congratulating a wise man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:72
verses.text: He said to them, If you stop praising me, I think myself something great after your departure; but if you do not stop praising me, I guess my own impurity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:73
verses.text: Feigned praise is worth less than true censure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:74
verses.text: Book 2 Sermon , on the Lazy and Indolent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:75
verses.text: To the weak and infirm, what is moderate appears excessive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:76
verses.text: Book 2 Sermon , on Your Neighbour—That You are to Bear His Burdens, Etc.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:77
verses.text: The reproof that is given with knowledge is very faithful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:78
verses.text: Sometimes also the knowledge of those who are condemned is found to be the most perfect demonstration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:79
verses.text: Book 2 Sermon , on the Proud, and Those Desirous of Vainglory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:80
verses.text: To the man who exalts and magnifies himself is attached the quick transition and the fall to low estate, as the divine word teaches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:81
verses.text: Book 2 Sermon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:82
verses.text: Pure speech and a spotless life are the throne and true temple of God.

verses.text: Maximus, Sermon.
