verses.text: —John of Damascus, 2 Chap—Antonius Melissa, Book 1 Sermon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:90
verses.text: Flattery is the bane of friendship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:91
verses.text: Most men are accustomed to pay court to the good fortune of princes, rather than to the princes themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:92
verses.text: Maximus, Sermon , p—Antonius Melissa, Sermon , p.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:93
verses.text: , and Sermon , p  The lovers of frugality shun luxury as the bane of soul and body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:94
verses.text: The possession and use of necessaries has nothing injurious in quality, but it has in quantity above measure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:95
verses.text: Scarcity of food is a necessary benefit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:96
verses.text: Maximus, Sermon , p—Antonius Melissa, Book 1 Sermon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:97
verses.text: The vivid remembrance of death is a check upon diet; and when the diet is lessened, the passions are diminished along with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:98
verses.text: Maximus, Sermon , p  Above all, Christians are not allowed to correct with violence the delinquencies of sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:99
verses.text: For it is not those that abstain from wickedness from compulsion, but those that abstain from choice, that God crowns.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:100
verses.text: It is impossible for a man to be steadily good except by his own choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:101
verses.text: For he that is made good by compulsion of another is not good; for he is not what he is by his own choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:102
verses.text: For it is the freedom of each one that makes true goodness and reveals real wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 5:103
verses.text: Whence through these dispositions God contrived to make His own disposition manifest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:1
verses.text: 11—Fragments Found in Greek Only in the Oxford Edition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:2
verses.text: From the Last Work on the Passover.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:3
verses.text: (Quoted in the Paschal Chronicle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:4
verses.text: )  Accordingly, in the years gone by, Jesus went to eat the passover sacrificed by the Jews, keeping the feast.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:5
verses.text: But when he had preached He who was the Passover, the Lamb of God, led as a sheep to the slaughter, presently taught His disciples the mystery of the type on the thirteenth day, on which also they inquired, "Where wilt Thou that we prepare for Thee to eat the passover?" It was on this day, then, that both the consecration of the unleavened bread and the preparation for the feast took place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:6
verses.text: Whence John naturally describes the disciples as already previously prepared to have their feet washed by the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:7
verses.text: And on the following day our Saviour suffered, He who was the Passover, propitiously sacrificed by the Jews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:8
verses.text: The Same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:9
verses.text: Suitably, therefore, to the fourteenth day, on which He also suffered, in the morning, the chief priests and the scribes, who brought Him to Pilate, did not enter the Praetorium, that they might not be defiled, but might freely eat the passover in the evening.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:10
verses.text: With this precise determination of the days both the whole Scriptures agree, and the Gospels harmonize.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:11
verses.text: The resurrection also attests it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:12
verses.text: He certainly rose on the third day, which fell on the first day of the weeks of harvest, on which the law prescribed that the priest should offer up the sheaf.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:13
verses.text: Macarius Chrysocephalus: Parable of the Prodigal Son, Luke 15 -, Oration on Luke 15 -, Towards the Close.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:14
verses.text: What choral dance and high festival is held in heaven, if there is one that has become an exile and a fugitive from the life led under the Father, knowing not that those who put themselves  far from Him shall perish; if he has squandered the gift, and substance, and inheritance of the Father; if there is one whose faith has failed, and whose hope is spent, by rushing along with the Gentiles into the same profligacy of debauchery; and then, famished and destitute, and not even filled with what the swine eat, has arisen and come to his Father!  But the kind Father waits not till the son comes to Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:15
verses.text: For perchance he would never be able or venture to approach, did he not find Him gracious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:16
verses.text: Wherefore, when he merely wishing, when he straightway made a beginning, when he took the first step, while he was yet a great way off, He the Father was moved with compassion, and ran, and fell upon his neck and kissed him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:17
verses.text: And then the son, taking courage, confessed what he had done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:18
verses.text: Wherefore the Father bestows on him the glory and honour that was due and meet, putting on him the best robe, the robe of immortality; and a ring, a royal signet and divine seal,—impress of consecration, signature of glory, pledge of testimony (for it is said, "He hath set to his seal that God is true,") and shoes, not those perishable ones which he hath set his foot on holy ground is bidden take off, nor such as he who is sent to preach the kingdom of heaven is forbidden to put on, but such as wear not, and are suited for the journey to heaven, becoming and adorning the heavenly path, such as unwashed feet never put on, but those which are washed by our Teacher and Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:19
verses.text: Many, truly, are the shoes of the sinful soul, by which it is bound and cramped.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:20
verses.text: For each man is cramped by the cords of his own sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:21
verses.text: Accordingly, Abraham swears to the king of Sodom, "I will not take of all that is thine, from a thread to a shoe-latchet".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:22
verses.text: On account of these being defiled and polluted on the earth, every kind of wrong and selfishness engrosses life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:23
verses.text: As the Lord reproves Israel by Amos, saying, "For three iniquities of Israel, yea, for four, I will not turn him back; because they have given away the righteous for silver, and the needy for a pair of shoes, which tread upon the dust of the ground".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:24
verses.text: Now the shoes which the Father bids the servant give to the repentant son who has betaken himself to Him, do not impede or drag to the earth (for the earthly tabernacle weighs down the anxious mind); but they are buoyant, and ascending, and waft to heaven, and serve as such a ladder and chariot as he requires who has turned his mind towards the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:25
verses.text: For, beautiful after being first beautifully adorned with all these things without, he enters into the gladness within.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:26
verses.text: For "Bring out" was said by Him who had first said, "While he was yet a great way off, he ran and fell upon his neck".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:27
verses.text: For it is here that all the preparation for entrance to the marriage to which we are invited must be accomplished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:28
verses.text: He, then, who has been made ready to enter will say, "This my joy is fulfilled".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:29
verses.text: But the unlovely and unsightly man will hear, "Friend, how camest thou in here, without having a wedding garment?" And the fat and unctuous food,—the delicacies abundant and sufficing of the blessed,—the fatted calf is killed; which is also again spoken of as a lamb (not literally); that no one may suppose it small; but it is the great and greatest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:30
verses.text: For not small is "the Lamb of God who taketh away the sin of the world," who "was led as a sheep to the slaughter," the sacrifice full of marrow, all whose fat, according to the sacred law, was the Lord's.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:31
verses.text: For He was wholly devoted and consecrated to the Lord; so well grown, and to such excessive size, as to reach and extend over all, and to fill those who eat Him and feed upon Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:32
verses.text: For He is both flesh and bread, and has given Himself as both to us to be eaten.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:33
verses.text: To the sons, then, who come to Him, the Father gives the calf, and it is slain and eaten.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:34
verses.text: But those who do not come to Him He pursues and disinherits, and is found to be a most powerful bull.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:35
verses.text: Here, by reason of His size and prowess, it is said of Him, "His glory is as that of an unicorn".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:36
verses.text: And the prophet Habakkuk sees Him bearing horns, and celebrates His defensive attitude—"horns in His hands".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:37
verses.text: Wherefore the sign shows His power and authority,—horns that pierce on both sides, or rather, on all sides, and through everything.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:38
verses.text: And those who eat are so strengthened, and retain such strength from the life-giving food in them, that they themselves are stronger than their enemies, and are all but armed with the horns of a bull; as it is said, "In thee shall we butt our enemies".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:39
verses.text: Gladness there is, and music, and dances; although the elder son, who had ever been with and ever obedient to the Father, takes it ill, when he who never had himself been dissipated or profligate sees the guilty one made happy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:40
verses.text: Accordingly the Father calls him, saying, "Son, thou art ever with me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:41
verses.text: And what greater joy and feast and festivity can be than being continually with God, standing by His side and serving Him? "And all that is mine is thine".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:42
verses.text: And blessed is the heir of God, for whom the  Father holds possession,—the faithful, to whom the whole world of possessions belongs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:43
verses.text: "It was meet that we should be glad, and rejoice; for thy brother was dead, and is alive again".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:44
verses.text: Kind Father, who givest all things life, and raisest the dead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:45
verses.text: "And was lost, and is found".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:46
verses.text: And "blessed is the man whom Thou hast chosen and accepted," and whom having sought, Thou dost find.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:47
verses.text: "Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven, whose sins are covered".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:48
verses.text: It is for man to repent of sins; but let this be accompanied with a change that will not be checked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:49
verses.text: For he who does not act so shall be put to shame, because he has acted not with his whole heart, but in haste.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:50
verses.text: And it is ours to flee to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:51
verses.text: And let us endeavour after this ceaselessly and energetically.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:52
verses.text: For He says, "Come unto Me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:53
verses.text: And prayer and confession with humility are voluntary acts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:54
verses.text: Wherefore it is enjoined, "First tell thy sins, that thou mayest be justified".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:55
verses.text: What afterwards we shall obtain, and what we shall be, it is not for us to judge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:56
verses.text: Such is the strict meaning of the parable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:57
verses.text: The repentant son came to the pitying Father, never hoping for these things,—the best robe, and the ring, and the shoes,—or to taste the fatted calf, or to share in gladness, or enjoy music and dances; but he would have been contented with obtaining what in his own estimation he deemed himself worth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:58
verses.text: "Make me," he had made up his mind to say, "as one of thy hired servants".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:59
verses.text: But when he saw the Father's welcome meeting him, he did not say this, but said what he had in his mind to say first, "Father, I have sinned against Heaven, and before thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:60
verses.text: And so both his humility and his accusation became the cause of justification and glory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:61
verses.text: For the righteous man condemns himself in his first words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:62
verses.text: So also the publican departed justified rather than the Pharisee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:63
verses.text: The son, then, knew not either what he was to obtain, or how to take or use or put on himself the things given him; since he did not take the robe himself, and put it on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:64
verses.text: But it is said, "Put it on him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:65
verses.text: He did not himself put the ring on his finger, but those who were bidden "Put a ring on his hand".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:66
verses.text: Nor did he put the shoes on himself, but it was they who heard, "and shoes on his feet".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:67
verses.text: And these things were perhaps incredible to him and to others, and unexpected before they took place; but gladly received and praised were the gifts with which he was presented.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:68
verses.text: The parable exhibits this thought, that the exercise of the faculty of reason has been accorded to each man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:69
verses.text: Wherefore the prodigal is introduced, demanding from his father his portion, that is, of the state of mind, endowed by reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:70
verses.text: For the possession of reason is granted to all, in order to the pursuit of what is good, and the avoidance of what is bad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:71
verses.text: But many who are furnished by God with this make a bad use of the knowledge that has been given them, and land in the profligacy of evil practices, and wickedly waste the substance of reason,—the eye on disgraceful sights, the tongue on blasphemous words, the smell on foetid licentious excesses of pleasures, the mouth on swinish gluttony, the hands on thefts, the feet on running into plots, the thoughts on impious counsels, the inclinations on indulgence on the love of ease, the mind on brutish pastime.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:72
verses.text: They preserve nothing of the substance of reason unsquandered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:73
verses.text: Such an one, therefore, Christ represents in the parable,—as a rational creature, with his reason darkened, and asking from the Divine Being what is suitable to reason; then as obtaining from God, and making a wicked use of what had been given, and especially of the benefits of baptism, which had been vouchsafed to him; whence also He calls him a prodigal; and then, after the dissipation of what had been given him, and again his restoration by repentance, He represents the love of God shown to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:74
verses.text: For He says, "Bring hither the fatted calf, kill it, and let us eat and be merry; for this my son"—a name of nearest relationship, and significative of what is given to the faithful—"was dead and lost,"—an expression of extremest alienation; for what is more alien to the living than the lost and dead? For neither can be possessed any more.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:75
verses.text: But having from the nearest relationship fallen to extremest alienation, again by repentance he returned to near relationship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:76
verses.text: For it is said, "Put on him the best robe," which was his the moment he obtained baptism.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:77
verses.text: I mean the glory of baptism, the remission of sins, and the communication of the other blessings, which he obtained immediately he had touched the font.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:78
verses.text: "And put a ring on his hand".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:79
verses.text: Here is the mystery of the Trinity; which is the seal impressed on those who believe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:80
verses.text: "And put shoes on his feet," for "the preparation of the Gospel of peace," and the whole course that leads to good actions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:81
verses.text: But whom Christ finds lost, after sin committed since baptism, those Novatus, enemy of God, resigns to destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:82
verses.text: Do not let us then reckon any fault if we repent; guarding against falling, let us, if we have fallen, retrace our steps.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:83
verses.text: And while dreading to offend, let us, after offending,  avoid despair, and be eager to be confirmed; and on sinking, let us haste to rise up again.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:84
verses.text: Let us obey the Lord, who calls to us, "Come unto Me, all ye that labour, and I will give you rest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:85
verses.text: Let us employ the gift of reason for actions of prudence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:86
verses.text: Let us learn now abstinence from what is wicked, that we may not be forced to learn in the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:87
verses.text: Let us employ life as a training school for what is good; and let us be roused to the hatred of sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:88
verses.text: Let us bear about a deep love for the Creator; let us cleave to Him with our whole heart; let us not wickedly waste the substance of reason, like the prodigal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 6:89
verses.text: Let us obtain the joy laid up, in which Paul exulting, exclaimed, "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ?" To Him belongs glory and honour, with the Father and the Holy Spirit, world without end, Amen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:2
verses.text: —Book 13 Chapter - 9  Possibly by the "iota and the tittle" His righteousness exclaims, "If ye come right to me, I also will come right to you; if ye walk crooked, I also will walk crooked, saith the Lord of hosts," alluding to the offences of sinners under the name of crooked ways.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:3
verses.text: For the straight way, and that according to nature, which is pointed out by the iota of Jesus, is His goodness, which is immoveable towards those who have obediently believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:4
verses.text: There shall not then pass away from the law neither the iota nor the tittle; that is, neither the promise that applies to the straight in the way, nor the punishment threatened against those that diverge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:10
verses.text: Whatever one, then, does to man, whether good or bad, is referred to Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 7:11
verses.text: Wherefore from Him judgment shall proceed, appointing to all according to desert; for He will avenge His own image.

verses.text: How? Not by putting off the body! Far be it! For with it as His own He shall come, the Judge of all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 8:68
verses.text: But by divesting Himself of physical affections, such as hunger, and thirst, and sleep, and weariness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 8:69

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Fragments 8:70
verses.text: As "after the flesh" in our case is being in the midst of sins, and being out of them is to be "not after the flesh;" so also after the flesh, in the case of Christ, was His subjection to natural affections, and not to be subject to them was not to be "after the flesh".
